title: 108_s1476
content: The Wind Power Tax Incentives Act of 2003 may be cited as the Wind Power Tax Incentives Act. It allows for the offset of passive activity losses and credits of an eligible taxpayer from wind energy facilities. The Wind Power Tax Incentives Act of 2003, also known as the Wind Power Tax Incentives Act, allows eligible taxpayers to offset passive activity losses and credits from wind energy facilities. This amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 exempts certain portions of passive activity losses and credits related to qualified facilities from taxation. The Wind Power Tax Incentives Act of 2003 allows taxpayers with adjusted gross income not exceeding $1,000,000 to offset passive activity losses and credits from wind energy facilities. Aggregation rules apply for single employers, and pass-thru entities allocate the credit at the person level. The amendments made by this section apply to facilities placed in service after the enactment of this Act. Credit for wind energy facilities of an eligible taxpayer allowed against minimum tax. Special rules for wind energy credit: The wind energy credit of an eligible taxpayer is subject to separate application under section 38(c) of the Internal Revenue Code. The tentative minimum tax is treated as zero, and the limitation under paragraph (1) is modified for this credit. The wind energy credit is a part of the renewable electric production credit for facilities using wind to generate electricity. The term "eligible taxpayer" is defined as per section 469(l)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code. Amendments are made to section 38(c) of the Code to accommodate the wind energy credit. Amendments to section 38(c) of the Internal Revenue Code include adding the wind energy credit. These changes will apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. APPLICATION OF CREDIT TO COOPERATIVES. Section 45(d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow cooperative organizations to allocate a portion of the credit to shareholders based on their capital contributions. The amendment to Section 45(d) of the Internal Revenue Code allows cooperative organizations to allocate a credit to shareholders based on their capital contributions. The election for the credit must be made on a timely filed return and is irrevocable for the taxable year. The amount of the credit apportioned to shareholders is not included in the organization's taxable income but is included in the shareholder's taxable income. The amendment to Section 45(d) of the Internal Revenue Code allows cooperative organizations to allocate a credit to shareholders based on their capital contributions. If the credit amount on the return is less than the actual credit, the excess is treated as an increase in tax on the organization. The amendment allows cooperative organizations to allocate a credit to shareholders based on their capital contributions. Any excess credit not claimed on the return is treated as an increase in tax on the organization. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the date of the enactment of this Act.
